questions.question: If a bar magnet is broken in half, what is the result?
options: Two smaller magnets, each with a North and a South pole.
One piece with only a North pole and one with only a South pole.
The pieces lose their magnetism entirely.
questions.explanation: Magnetic monopoles do not exist. Breaking a magnet results in two dipoles, each with its own North and South pole.

questions.question: The direction of a magnetic field line at any point is defined as the direction that:
options: The North pole of a compass needle would point.
A positive test charge would move.
A South pole of a compass needle would point.
questions.explanation: By international convention, magnetic field lines represent the path a north pole would follow, exiting from the North and entering the South.

questions.question: According to the Domain Theory of Magnetism, a piece of iron becomes magnetized when:
options: Individual magnetic domains align in the same direction.
It is heated to a very high temperature.
Electrons are removed from the surface of the metal.
It is placed in a vacuum.
questions.explanation: Ferromagnetic materials contain 'domains'—clusters of atoms with aligned magnetic moments. Magnetization occurs when these clusters align collectively.

questions.question: Which of the following materials is classified as 'ferromagnetic'?
questions.explanation: The primary ferromagnetic elements are Iron (Fe), Nickel (Ni), and Cobalt (Co).

questions.question: The Earth's 'Magnetic North' pole is physically located near the:
questions.explanation: Since the North end of a compass needle is attracted to the Arctic, the Earth's physical magnetic pole in the North is actually a magnetic South pole.

questions.question: A straight wire carries a current directed upward. According to the First Right-Hand Rule, the field lines are:
options: Circular loops in a counter-clockwise direction (viewed from above).
Directed radially outward from the wire.
Circular loops in a clockwise direction.
questions.explanation: Using the RHR: Thumb points with current (up), fingers curl in the direction of the field (counter-clockwise).

questions.question: What is the name of the phenomenon where a magnetic field is produced by an electric current?
questions.explanation: Electromagnetism is the interaction between electric currents and magnetic fields, first observed by Oersted in 1820.

questions.question: Inside a solenoid (a coil of wire), the magnetic field is:
questions.explanation: The fields from each loop in a solenoid reinforce each other in the center, creating a straight, uniform magnetic field.

questions.question: Which factor would NOT increase the strength of an electromagnet?
options: Increasing the resistance of the wire.
Increasing the number of turns in the coil.
Increasing the voltage of the power source.
questions.explanation: Increasing resistance decreases the current (I = V/R). Since the magnetic field B is proportional to I, the electromagnet would become weaker.

questions.question: What happens to the magnetic field around a wire if the current direction is reversed?
options: The magnetic field direction also reverses.
The field turns parallel to the wire.
questions.explanation: Magnetic field direction depends strictly on current direction; reversing the flow flips the orientation of the field loops.

scoreMessages.90: Excellent — you have a firm grasp of magnetic poles, fields, and electromagnetism basics.
scoreMessages.70: Solid performance — review the directional rules for currents and Earth's magnetism.
scoreMessages.50: Good start — focus on how domain theory and solenoids work to strengthen fields.
scoreMessages.0: Review the fundamental properties of magnets and the First Right-Hand Rule.
